title: Brexit: Boris Johnson loses showdown vote meaning he must ask for delay by law
text:

Boris Johnson is legally obliged to ask for a Brexit delay by 11pm tonight after he lost a historic vote in the House of Commons.

The humiliated PM faces breaking his "do or die" pledge to leave on October 31 after MPs voted 322-306 (majority 16) for a crucial amendment.

The result effectively means he must, by law, ask the EU for a three-month extension tonight - even if MPs end up backing his Brexit deal in the coming weeks.

But while not explicitly saying he'd break the law, the defiant PM today suggested he would be as difficult as possible - and refuse to "negotiate" any delay with the EU.

It came as Parliament sat on a Saturday for the first time in 37 years - while thousands of protesters stood outside demanding a second referendum.

Boris Johnson wanted to force MPs into a "meaningful vote" on his Brexit deal that would have 'locked in' a legal countdown to October 31.

But his plans for a moment in history were scuppered by ousted Tory Sir Oliver Letwin.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag)

MP Sir Oliver passed an amendment that will "withhold" approval for the Brexit deal "unless and until" every part of it has passed into UK law.

That means the Prime Minister doesn't have a deal agreed by Parliament yet.

So under a previous law called the Benn Act, he is legally obliged to write to the EU by 11pm tonight to ask for a Brexit delay to January 31.

Mr Johnson carefully avoided saying if he would or wouldn't send the legal letter asking for a delay.

But he said: "I will not negotiate a delay with the EU and neither does the law compel me to do so!"

The PM added: "I will tell our friends and colleagues in the EU exactly what I’ve told everyone in the last 88 days that I’ve served as Prime Minister: that further delay would be bad for this country, bad for the European Union and bad for democracy.

"Since I became Prime Minister I‘ve said we must get on and get Brexit done on October 31 so that this country can move on. That policy remains unchanged.

"No delays, and I will continue to do all I can to get Brexit done on October 31."

Asking for a delay and negotiating one are two different things - and the PM is only legally obliged to ask, not negotiate.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag)

"I'm absolutely certain he will comply with the law," said Sir Oliver Letwin.

Yet the PM's spokesman point blank refused to confirm if the delay letter would be sent by 11pm tonight - saying he had nothing to add to Mr Johnson's statement.

Jeremy Corbyn declared: "The Prime Minister must now comply with the law!" And he warned the Prime Minister must "think very carefully" about his apparent refusal to engage with extension.

Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson even said the Commons sitting should be briefly suspended so the Prime Minister could "go and send his letter" while MPs wait.

Naomi Smith, CEO of anti-Brexit group Best for Britain said: “The success of this amendment shows that MPs do not trust Boris Johnson not to run the country off a No-Deal cliff-edge a year down the line.

“The Prime Minister tried to bounce MPs into quickly nodding through a deal which makes Theresa May’s botched effort look good.

(Image: REUTERS)

“It’s another humiliation for the Prime Minister who can’t win a parliamentary vote.

“He must now do what is right for the country by requesting an extension from the EU, and averting the crisis he created through his last minute renegotiation.”

Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg will now make an emergency statement on Monday afternoon to reveal the government's next steps.

He said he planned to re-table today's motion to give MPs a "meaningful vote" on Boris Johnson's deal.

But the situation was unclear after Speaker John Bercow suggested tabling the motion again may be against Commons rules - and he'd only decide on Monday whether it would be allowed.

Meaningful vote or not, the government can still try to pass Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - which before today's hiccup was facing a knife-edge vote on approval.

Ministers can choose to bring forward the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which is a separate mechanism to code the deal into UK law.

Sir Oliver insisted his amendment was simply an insurance policy to ensure a no-deal Brexit didn't happen by accident on October 31.

Brexit will only have happened legally once MPs have held a series of further votes to pass a law called the Withdrawal Agreement Act.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag)

Sir Oliver feared no-deal would happen by accident if the Act got snarled up in Parliament, and wasn't complete before the October 31 deadline.

But his amendment meant MPs were denied a straight up-and-down "meaningful vote" on the Brexit deal today - with a decision now only due in the coming days and weeks instead.

If granted by 27 EU leaders, an extension may only last a matter of weeks - as long as Boris Johnson's Brexit deal is passed at a later date and enters into law.

But if the Brexit deal doesn't pass it could lead to further chaos with a possible vote of no confidence and general election .

Boris Johnson had begged Oliver Letwin to withdraw his ‘delay Brexit’ amendment - but the MP flatly refused, with allies suggesting he was more likely to play in the Rugby World Cup.

(Image: Tom Corban/REX)

(Image: PA)

Tory Iain Duncan Smith urged Sir Oliver to “withdraw his amendment and give the British people what they are dying for - a decision on Brexit.”

Boris Johnson said it was time to have a proper vote on the deal he won on Thursday, saying: "Let us come together as democrats to end this debilitating feud."

And Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove urged MPs to have a clean vote to end the "depression and dismay and demoralisation" saying it would be "a cloud has been lifted".

But Jeremy Corbyn - who backed the delay amendment - said: "I totally understand the frustration and the fatigue across the country and in this House.

"But we simply cannot vote for a deal that is even worse than the one the House rejected three times."

(Image: REUTERS)

It came as Parliament sat on a Saturday for the first time since 1982 to approve or reject Boris Johnson ’s Brexit deal.

At the same time, tens of thousands of protesters descended on Westminster demanding a second referendum – a “People’s Vote”.

But the vote risked becoming a damp squib after MP Oliver Letwin tabled his amendment to force a delay, win or lose - and put off the final decision until later.

That prompted No10 to threaten to pull or sit out the vote to avoid handing a symbolic victory to the expelled Tory and his Labour allies.

Today’s vote was already on a knife edge as victory hinged on just a few Labour MPs in Leave seats.

Boris Johnson finally agreed a Brexit deal with the EU on October 17 - keeping a transition period to December 2020 and the £39bn divorce bill, but scrapping the Irish backstop.

(Image: Peter Summers)

In the backstop's place would effectively be 'two borders' in a hybrid system:

Northern Ireland and Britain would share a legal customs territory - technically forcing customs checks on goods crossing the 310-mile border with the Republic.

But in practice, to avoid checks at the border, the checks will instead happen when goods reach Northern Ireland on the island of Ireland. Critics say this puts a customs border across the Irish Sea - more of this below.

Northern Ireland and the Republic would share some EU single market rules - forcing checks on manufactured and agricultural products crossing the Irish Sea.

The Northern Ireland Assembly - known as Stormont - will get a vote every four years on whether to let EU law continue. But this vote could be passed by a simple majority - denying the DUP a veto on staying under EU laws long-term.

(Image: Kiran Ridley)

Meanwhile commitments on workers' rights were deprioritised - moved to the non-legally-binding Political Declaration for agreement later.

Last night Boris Johnson unveiled a last-minute offer on workers’ rights after his deal watered them down. But it was slammed by Labour’s leadership and the TUC as not worth the paper it’s written on.

The PM was jeered by Labour MPs as he stood up at 9.30am today to insist he would protect workers' rights.

And DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds savaged the PM for breaking his promise never to create a customs border down the Irish Sea in an excoriating speech.

But some swung behind the Prime Minister including Theresa May - who accused anti-Brexit MPs of a 'con trick on the British people'.
description: The humiliating result on the Oliver Letwin amendment means the Prime Minister still has no closure on Brexit - yet he flatly refused to "negotiate" a delay, leaving the next steps up in the air
